title: 1 Kings Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 2.

questions.question: What did David charge Solomon to do before he died?
options: Be strong and show yourself a man
Build a temple for the Lord
Conquer all neighboring kingdoms
Write down the laws of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Be strong and show yourself a man
questions.explanation: David charged Solomon to be strong and show himself a man as stated in 1 Kings 2:2.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 2:3, what must Solomon keep to prosper in all that he does?
options: The charge of the LORD thy God, to walk in His ways
The riches and treasures of Israel
The friendship of all kings
The laws of the nations around
questions.correctAnswer: The charge of the LORD thy God, to walk in His ways
questions.explanation: Solomon was instructed to keep the charge of the LORD his God, including statutes and commandments, to prosper (1 Kings 2:3).

questions.question: Who did David tell Solomon not to let go down to the grave in peace because of what he did?
options: Joab the son of Zeruiah
Abiathar the priest
Shimei the son of Gera
Adonijah the son of Haggith
questions.correctAnswer: Joab the son of Zeruiah
questions.explanation: David instructed Solomon to deal wisely with Joab and not let his hoar head go down to the grave in peace (1 Kings 2:5-6).

questions.question: Who did David ask Solomon to show kindness to and let eat at his table?
options: The sons of Barzillai the Gileadite
The sons of Zeruiah
The priests of Shiloh
The servants of Achish
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Barzillai the Gileadite
questions.explanation: David asked Solomon to show kindness to the sons of Barzillai because they helped him when he fled from Absalom (1 Kings 2:7).

questions.question: What was the promise David swore to Shimei regarding his life?
options: That he would not put him to death with the sword
That he would make him a king
That he would exile him to another land
That he would imprison him for life
questions.correctAnswer: That he would not put him to death with the sword
questions.explanation: David swore by the LORD to Shimei that he would not put him to death with the sword (1 Kings 2:8).

questions.question: True or False: David was buried in the city of David after he died.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 2:10 states that David slept with his fathers and was buried in the city of David.

questions.question: How many years did David reign in Jerusalem according to 1 Kings 2:11?
options: Thirty and three years
Seven years
Forty years
Twenty years
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty and three years
questions.explanation: David reigned thirty and three years in Jerusalem (1 Kings 2:11).

questions.question: Who came to Bathsheba to ask for Abishag the Shunammite as a wife?
options: Adonijah the son of Haggith
Joab the son of Zeruiah
Abiathar the priest
Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
questions.correctAnswer: Adonijah the son of Haggith
questions.explanation: Adonijah came to Bathsheba to request Abishag the Shunammite as a wife (1 Kings 2:13-17).

questions.question: What was Solomon's response when Bathsheba asked him to give Abishag to Adonijah?
options: He asked why she requested Abishag for Adonijah and implied she should ask for the kingdom
He immediately agreed to the request
He ignored her petition
He told her to ask Joab instead
questions.correctAnswer: He asked why she requested Abishag for Adonijah and implied she should ask for the kingdom
questions.explanation: Solomon questioned why Bathsheba asked for Abishag for Adonijah and suggested she might as well ask for the kingdom (1 Kings 2:22).

questions.question: True or False: Solomon spared Abiathar the priest because he had been faithful in bearing the ark before David.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Solomon spared Abiathar because he had borne the ark and suffered with David (1 Kings 2:26).

questions.question: Where did Joab flee to when he was sought by Solomon?
options: The tabernacle of the LORD
The city of Gath
The wilderness
The house of Abiathar
questions.correctAnswer: The tabernacle of the LORD
questions.explanation: Joab fled to the tabernacle of the LORD and caught hold of the horns of the altar (1 Kings 2:28).

questions.question: Who did Solomon command to kill Joab?
options: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
Abiathar the priest
Adonijah the son of Haggith
Shimei the son of Gera
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: Solomon sent Benaiah to kill Joab as recorded in 1 Kings 2:29-34.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Solomon told Shimei to build a house in ______ and not leave it.
options: Jerusalem
Hebron
Gath
Mahanaim
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Solomon commanded Shimei to build a house in Jerusalem and not go anywhere else (1 Kings 2:36).

questions.question: True or False: When Shimei left Jerusalem to retrieve his servants, Solomon allowed him to go without question.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Solomon questioned Shimei for leaving Jerusalem despite his oath and later commanded his death (1 Kings 2:41-46).

questions.question: Who was put in the room over the host after Joab was killed?
options: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
Abiathar the priest
Adonijah the son of Haggith
Shimei the son of Gera
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: After Joab's death, Solomon appointed Benaiah over the host (1 Kings 2:35).

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Kings 2, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and strength?
options: Be strong and show yourself a man, keeping God's commandments to prosper
Avoid all trials by seeking comfort and ease
Depend only on your own wisdom and strength
Ignore God's statutes and focus on worldly success
questions.correctAnswer: Be strong and show yourself a man, keeping God's commandments to prosper
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 2:2-3 encourages strength and obedience to God's laws as the path to prosperity and success, emphasizing perseverance through faith and obedience.

questions.question: What does Solomon's charge to keep the charge of the LORD teach about faith and obedience in daily life?
options: Walking in God's ways leads to prosperity in all that you do
Obedience is optional and based on convenience
Only external rituals matter, not the heart
Prosperity comes from wealth and power alone
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in God's ways leads to prosperity in all that you do
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 2:3 teaches that keeping God's statutes and commandments leads to success and blessing in life, highlighting the importance of faithfulness and obedience.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 2 instruct us about dealing with past wrongs and justice in leadership?
options: Act wisely and bring justice even if it requires difficult decisions
Ignore past wrongs to maintain peace at all costs
Seek revenge without wisdom or counsel
Be lenient to all offenders regardless of their actions
questions.correctAnswer: Act wisely and bring justice even if it requires difficult decisions
questions.explanation: David charged Solomon to deal wisely with Joab for past bloodshed (1 Kings 2:5-6, 9), illustrating that justice and wisdom are vital in leadership and personal integrity.

questions.question: A believer asks how to practice kindness and gratitude in relationships. What example from 1 Kings 2 can you share?
options: Show kindness to the sons of Barzillai who were faithful in times of trouble
Ignore those who helped you in the past
Only help those who are powerful and influential
Seek favors from others without reciprocating
questions.correctAnswer: Show kindness to the sons of Barzillai who were faithful in times of trouble
questions.explanation: David instructed Solomon to show kindness to Barzillai's sons because of their loyalty during his flight from Absalom (1 Kings 2:7), teaching gratitude and faithful relationships.

questions.question: What does Solomon’s handling of Adonijah’s petition teach about humility and rightful authority?
options: Recognize God’s sovereign choice and do not yield your God-given authority
Ignore petitions from family members
Allow anyone to claim rights without consequence
Avoid difficult conversations about leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God’s sovereign choice and do not yield your God-given authority
questions.explanation: Solomon acknowledges that the kingdom belongs to him by God’s appointment and denies Adonijah’s request, teaching humility in respecting God’s authority and rightful leadership (1 Kings 2:15, 22).

questions.question: How does Solomon’s response to Bathsheba’s request model integrity and honesty in leadership?
options: He honestly confronts the real issue behind the request and acts according to justice
He grants every request without consideration
He bypasses justice to please his mother
He ignores requests from his family
questions.correctAnswer: He honestly confronts the real issue behind the request and acts according to justice
questions.explanation: Solomon questions why Bathsheba asks for Abishag for Adonijah and then orders Adonijah’s death, showing integrity and commitment to justice rather than favoritism (1 Kings 2:22-24).

questions.question: What principle about stewardship and consequences does the story of Shimei illustrate?
options: Obedience to God’s commands and promises is crucial, and breaking them leads to consequences
You can disregard God’s commands if you made a promise
Promises to God are not important
Disobedience has no real consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s commands and promises is crucial, and breaking them leads to consequences
questions.explanation: Shimei’s disobedience to Solomon’s command leads to his death (1 Kings 2:36-46), showing the importance of faithfulness and the consequences of breaking God’s word.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 2, Solomon showed kindness and allowed Abiathar to remain priest despite his disobedience.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Solomon removed Abiathar from the priesthood because of disobedience, though he did not kill him immediately out of respect for past service (1 Kings 2:26-27).

questions.question: True or False: Solomon’s establishment on the throne was described as greatly established and divinely confirmed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 2:12 states Solomon’s kingdom was greatly established, affirming God’s blessing and confirmation on his reign.

questions.question: How does Solomon’s instruction to Benaiah about Joab teach about dealing with sin and leadership accountability?
options: Leaders must be held accountable for their sins to maintain justice and peace
Sin in leadership should be ignored to avoid conflict
Favoritism should protect sinful leaders
Punishment is unnecessary if the sin was unknown
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must be held accountable for their sins to maintain justice and peace
questions.explanation: Solomon orders Joab’s death to remove innocent blood and establish peace, showing that leadership demands accountability (1 Kings 2:29-34).

questions.question: A friend struggles with forgiveness and justice. Based on 1 Kings 2, what biblical balance can you share?
options: Show kindness to faithful friends but act justly with those who harm others
Forgive all without holding anyone accountable
Seek revenge for every wrong
Ignore kindness and focus only on justice
questions.correctAnswer: Show kindness to faithful friends but act justly with those who harm others
questions.explanation: David’s charge to Solomon to show kindness to Barzillai’s sons but bring justice to Joab (1 Kings 2:6-7) teaches balancing mercy and justice in relationships.

questions.question: How does the chapter teach about humility and contentment in family life?
options: Accept God’s will for leadership and do not seek to usurp what is not yours
Demand what you believe you deserve regardless of God’s will
Ignore God’s plan for your life
Contest leadership and cause division
questions.correctAnswer: Accept God’s will for leadership and do not seek to usurp what is not yours
questions.explanation: Adonijah admits the kingdom is Solomon’s by God’s choice (1 Kings 2:15), teaching submission to God’s plan and humility in family roles.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David told Solomon to keep the charge of the LORD, to walk in His ways, and keep His statutes, commandments, judgments, and __________, to prosper in all you do.
options: testimonies
miracles
traditions
offerings
questions.correctAnswer: testimonies
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 2:3 commands Solomon to keep the LORD’s testimonies along with His commandments and statutes to prosper.

questions.question: What does the removal of Abiathar from the priesthood symbolize about integrity and faithfulness in service to God?
options: Disobedience has consequences even for those who have served faithfully
Past service guarantees indefinite favor regardless of actions
Position in the church is permanent and cannot be revoked
Faithfulness is unnecessary if you have status
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience has consequences even for those who have served faithfully
questions.explanation: Solomon removed Abiathar to fulfill God’s word, despite his past faithfulness, teaching that integrity requires continuous obedience (1 Kings 2:26-27).

questions.question: How can the story of Joab’s death encourage believers to pursue honesty and repentance?
options: Sin unrepented can bring judgment, even for those close to God
Sin is overlooked if you are loyal
Violence is the only solution to sin
Ignore past sins and focus on the future
questions.correctAnswer: Sin unrepented can bring judgment, even for those close to God
questions.explanation: Joab’s execution for past murders despite loyalty to David (1 Kings 2:32-34) shows that repentance and honesty are necessary to avoid judgment.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 2.

questions.question: What charge did David give Solomon regarding his conduct before God as he was about to die?
options: To be strong and show himself a man, keeping the charge of the LORD in all ways
To seek alliances with neighboring kingdoms for peace
To build a great temple for the LORD in Jerusalem
To punish all his enemies immediately upon ascending the throne
questions.correctAnswer: To be strong and show himself a man, keeping the charge of the LORD in all ways
questions.explanation: David charged Solomon to be strong and walk in the statutes and commandments of the LORD (1 Kings 2:2-3), emphasizing obedience as the key to prosperity and kingdom stability.

questions.question: Which two captains of the hosts did Joab kill, and what was the significance of this act according to David's charge to Solomon?
options: Abner and Amasa; Joab shed blood in peace which was a grievous offense
Gideon and Barak; they were innocent leaders of Israel
Saul and Jonathan; they were former kings and princes
Zeruiah and Abishai; they were Joab’s own brothers
questions.correctAnswer: Abner and Amasa; Joab shed blood in peace which was a grievous offense
questions.explanation: David reminded Solomon that Joab killed Abner and Amasa, shedding blood during peace times, which was considered a serious crime (1 Kings 2:5), instructing Solomon to deal with Joab accordingly.

questions.question: What promise did David mention concerning the throne of Israel if his children walk before God in truth and with all their heart and soul?
options: There shall not fail a man on the throne of Israel
They will have wealth and prosperity without end
They will conquer all neighboring nations
Their descendants will become priests and prophets
questions.correctAnswer: There shall not fail a man on the throne of Israel
questions.explanation: David cited God's word that if his children walk in truth with all their heart, the throne of Israel would never be without a man on it (1 Kings 2:4), highlighting the conditional nature of the Davidic covenant.

questions.question: What was Solomon’s response when Bathsheba asked him to give Abishag the Shunammite to Adonijah as a wife?
options: He questioned why she asked for Abishag and implied Adonijah’s request was a claim to the kingdom
He immediately agreed to the request out of respect for his mother
He ignored the request and changed the subject
He imprisoned Adonijah for making such a request
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why she asked for Abishag and implied Adonijah’s request was a claim to the kingdom
questions.explanation: Solomon responded by pointing out that asking for Abishag was tantamount to asking for the kingdom, thus revealing Adonijah’s ambition (1 Kings 2:22).

questions.question: What action did Solomon take against Adonijah after his request through Bathsheba?
options: He had Adonijah put to death that same day
He banished Adonijah to exile in Gath
He imprisoned Adonijah indefinitely
He made peace and gave him a position in the army
questions.correctAnswer: He had Adonijah put to death that same day
questions.explanation: Solomon ordered Benaiah to kill Adonijah because his request was seen as a threat to Solomon’s reign (1 Kings 2:24-25).

questions.question: What was the significance of Solomon removing Abiathar from the priesthood?
options: It fulfilled the LORD’s word concerning the house of Eli
It was a reward for Abiathar’s loyalty to David
It was a political alliance with the Philistines
It was a temporary measure until a new priest was found
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfilled the LORD’s word concerning the house of Eli
questions.explanation: Solomon’s removal of Abiathar fulfilled the prophecy about the downfall of Eli’s house (1 Kings 2:27), linking the political and religious leadership changes.

questions.question: Why did Joab flee to the tabernacle and grasp the horns of the altar?
options: To seek asylum and avoid execution
To worship the LORD before battle
To make a sacrifice for Solomon’s success
To challenge Solomon’s authority publicly
questions.correctAnswer: To seek asylum and avoid execution
questions.explanation: Joab fled to the tabernacle and caught hold of the altar horns to claim sanctuary from Solomon’s decree of death (1 Kings 2:28).

questions.question: How did Solomon ultimately handle Joab’s claim to sanctuary at the altar?
options: He ordered Benaiah to kill Joab despite his plea to stay at the altar
He pardoned Joab and allowed him to serve in the army
He sent Joab into exile to the wilderness
He imprisoned Joab within the temple precincts
questions.correctAnswer: He ordered Benaiah to kill Joab despite his plea to stay at the altar
questions.explanation: Solomon instructed Benaiah to execute Joab, removing innocent blood from the house of David (1 Kings 2:29-34).

questions.question: What role did Benaiah the son of Jehoiada assume after Joab’s death?
options: Commander over the army in Joab’s place
Chief priest replacing Abiathar
Royal scribe and advisor to Solomon
Governor of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Commander over the army in Joab’s place
questions.explanation: After Joab was killed, Benaiah was appointed by Solomon as the new commander of the host (1 Kings 2:35).

questions.question: What was the condition Solomon imposed on Shimei when he allowed him to live in Jerusalem?
options: Shimei should not leave Jerusalem or cross the brook Kidron
Shimei must serve in the army to prove loyalty
Shimei must build a new temple in Jerusalem
Shimei must pay tribute annually to Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: Shimei should not leave Jerusalem or cross the brook Kidron
questions.explanation: Solomon commanded Shimei to stay in Jerusalem and warned him that if he left and crossed the brook Kidron, he would die (1 Kings 2:36-37).

questions.question: What happened when Shimei violated Solomon’s command and left Jerusalem?
options: He was executed by Benaiah on Solomon’s orders
He was forgiven after explaining his reasons
He was exiled to Gath permanently
He was imprisoned by Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: He was executed by Benaiah on Solomon’s orders
questions.explanation: After Shimei left Jerusalem and returned, Solomon ordered Benaiah to put him to death as punishment for breaking his oath (1 Kings 2:41-46).

questions.question: True or False: David’s charge to Solomon emphasizes obedience to the LORD’s commandments as the key to establishing his kingdom and securing the throne.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David instructs Solomon to keep the charge of the LORD and promises that if his children walk before God in truth, the throne will be established (1 Kings 2:3-4).

questions.question: How does Solomon’s dealing with his enemies in 1 Kings 2 illustrate the fulfillment of divine justice as prophesied in earlier scriptures?
options: By executing Joab and Abiathar, fulfilling the word concerning the house of Eli
By building the temple exactly as Moses commanded
By conquering the Philistines as promised to Abraham
By restoring the Ark of the Covenant to Shiloh
questions.correctAnswer: By executing Joab and Abiathar, fulfilling the word concerning the house of Eli
questions.explanation: Solomon’s removal of Abiathar and execution of Joab fulfilled the LORD’s prophecy regarding Eli’s descendants (1 Kings 2:27), showing divine justice and covenantal faithfulness.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in David's final charge to Solomon where promises of prosperity and warnings against enemies are interwoven?
options: Chiasm, highlighting the central theme of obedience and kingdom stability
Parable, illustrating moral lessons through story
Allegory, representing the kingdom as a vineyard
Foreshadowing, predicting Solomon's temple building
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, highlighting the central theme of obedience and kingdom stability
questions.explanation: David’s charge uses chiasm by placing the emphasis on obedience to God at the center, with promises and warnings framing the message (1 Kings 2:1-4).

questions.question: Which Old Testament covenant is primarily alluded to in David’s charge to Solomon about walking in God’s statutes and commandments?
options: The Mosaic Covenant
The Abrahamic Covenant
The Noahic Covenant
The Davidic Covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The Mosaic Covenant
questions.explanation: David refers to the law of Moses and commandments (1 Kings 2:3), indicating that Solomon’s obedience to Mosaic law is essential for his prosperity and the kingdom’s continuation.

questions.question: How does the historical context of ancient Near Eastern royal succession influence Solomon’s actions toward Adonijah and Joab?
options: Eliminating rivals secured Solomon’s divine right and political stability
Royal succession was always peaceful and based on primogeniture only
Kings typically abdicated voluntarily to their brothers
Military generals were often exempt from royal punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Eliminating rivals secured Solomon’s divine right and political stability
questions.explanation: Solomon’s execution of Adonijah and Joab reflects the ancient Near Eastern practice of consolidating power by removing threats to the throne (1 Kings 2:24-34).

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What primary charge did David give to Solomon regarding his conduct before God?
options: To be strong and show himself a man
To conquer all his enemies
To build a temple for the Lord
To gather wealth and horses
questions.correctAnswer: To be strong and show himself a man
questions.explanation: David charged Solomon to be strong and show himself a man (1 Kings 2:2), which aligns with exhortations in Scripture to be courageous and faithful leaders, as seen in Joshua 1:6-7, 1 Corinthians 16:13, Ephesians 6:10, and 2 Timothy 1:7.

questions.question: According to David’s charge, what was the condition for Solomon's prosperity in all he did?
options: To keep the charge of the LORD by walking in His statutes and commandments
To amass great armies
To form alliances with neighboring nations
To build a strong palace
questions.correctAnswer: To keep the charge of the LORD by walking in His statutes and commandments
questions.explanation: David instructed Solomon to keep God's statutes and commandments to prosper (1 Kings 2:3). This reflects the covenant principle seen in Deuteronomy 28:1-2, Psalm 1:1-3, Proverbs 3:5-6, and James 1:25, where obedience to God leads to blessing.

questions.question: What promise from God concerning David’s descendants did David remind Solomon to uphold?
options: That a man shall not fail to sit on the throne of Israel if his children walk truthfully before God
That the temple would never be destroyed
That Israel would never be taken into exile
That Solomon would reign forever
questions.correctAnswer: That a man shall not fail to sit on the throne of Israel if his children walk truthfully before God
questions.explanation: David reminded Solomon of God's promise that if his descendants walk truthfully with all heart and soul, no man will fail on Israel's throne (1 Kings 2:4). This covenantal promise is foundational and echoed in 2 Samuel 7:16, Psalm 89:3-4, Jeremiah 33:17, and Luke 1:32-33, affirming the Davidic covenant and messianic hope.

questions.question: What was David’s instruction regarding Joab, who had shed blood in peace and killed two captains?
options: That Joab’s old age should not go down to the grave in peace
That Joab should be honored for his past service
That Joab should be sent into exile
That Joab should be made chief advisor to Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: That Joab’s old age should not go down to the grave in peace
questions.explanation: David charged Solomon not to let Joab die in peace because of his violent deeds (1 Kings 2:6). This reflects biblical justice principles seen in Numbers 35:33-34, Deuteronomy 19:10-13, Romans 12:19, and Hebrews 10:30, emphasizing accountability for sin.

questions.question: What kindness did David instruct Solomon to show in regard to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite?
options: To let them eat at Solomon’s table
To give them lands in Jerusalem
To make them priests
To appoint them as generals
questions.correctAnswer: To let them eat at Solomon’s table
questions.explanation: David told Solomon to show kindness to Barzillai’s sons by allowing them to eat at his table (1 Kings 2:7). This reflects biblical themes of hospitality and reward for faithfulness seen in Genesis 18:3, Ruth 2:14, Matthew 25:35, and Hebrews 13:2.

questions.question: How did Solomon respond to Bathsheba’s request for Abishag the Shunammite to be given to Adonijah as a wife?
options: He questioned why she asked for Abishag and insinuated that she might as well ask for the kingdom
He immediately granted the request
He ignored the request
He imprisoned Adonijah
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why she asked for Abishag and insinuated that she might as well ask for the kingdom
questions.explanation: Solomon questioned Bathsheba’s request for Abishag for Adonijah and implied that asking for her was tantamount to asking for the kingdom (1 Kings 2:22). This reveals Solomon's awareness of political threats, consistent with biblical themes of wisdom and discernment in Proverbs 2:11, Ecclesiastes 8:5, Matthew 10:16, and James 1:5.

questions.question: Who did Solomon order to execute Adonijah, and why?
options: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, because Adonijah had spoken against his own life by requesting Abishag
Joab, because he was rebellious
Abiathar, because he supported Adonijah
Shimei, because he was cursed
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, because Adonijah had spoken against his own life by requesting Abishag
questions.explanation: Solomon commanded Benaiah to kill Adonijah since his petition for Abishag was viewed as a threat to Solomon’s reign (1 Kings 2:23-25). This action aligns with divine justice and kingship authority seen in Exodus 18:21, Deuteronomy 17:18-20, Romans 13:1-4, and Hebrews 13:17.

questions.question: What was Solomon’s decision regarding Abiathar the priest, and what was the reason?
options: Abiathar was removed from priesthood but not killed due to his past service and suffering with David
Abiathar was promoted to high priest
Abiathar was exiled without any honor
Abiathar was executed immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar was removed from priesthood but not killed due to his past service and suffering with David
questions.explanation: Solomon removed Abiathar from the priesthood but spared his life because he had faithfully served David and shared in his afflictions (1 Kings 2:26). This reflects biblical mercy and fulfillment of prophecy, as in Numbers 27:18-23, 1 Samuel 2:27-36, Luke 1:5, and Hebrews 7:23-24.

questions.question: Where did Joab flee when he sought refuge, and what was Solomon’s response?
options: The tabernacle of the LORD; Solomon ordered Benaiah to kill him even there
The house of Abiathar; Solomon pardoned him
Jerusalem palace; Solomon imprisoned him
A foreign land; Solomon sent envoys to capture him
questions.correctAnswer: The tabernacle of the LORD; Solomon ordered Benaiah to kill him even there
questions.explanation: Joab fled to the tabernacle and caught hold of the altar’s horns for sanctuary, but Solomon still commanded Benaiah to kill him there (1 Kings 2:28-31). This demonstrates God's justice prevailing over sanctuary rights, consistent with Exodus 21:12-14, 1 Kings 1:50-53, Luke 20:19-20, and Hebrews 12:29.

questions.question: What theological reason does Solomon give for the blood avenged upon Joab?
options: Joab killed two men more righteous than himself, and their blood would return upon him
Joab had stolen from the temple treasury
Joab had rebelled against the king publicly
Joab had cursed the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Joab killed two men more righteous than himself, and their blood would return upon him
questions.explanation: Solomon cited Joab’s murder of Abner and Amasa, who were more righteous, as the reason for divine retribution upon Joab (1 Kings 2:32-33). This is consistent with biblical principles of divine justice in Numbers 35:30, Proverbs 11:31, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 6:10-11.

questions.question: What position did Solomon give to Benaiah after Joab’s death?
options: Over the host in Joab’s place
Chief priest
Royal scribe
Governor of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Over the host in Joab’s place
questions.explanation: Solomon appointed Benaiah over the army, replacing Joab, as stated in 1 Kings 2:35. This reflects God-ordained leadership succession and faithful service, paralleling Joshua 1:14, 1 Samuel 13:14, 2 Timothy 2:2, and Hebrews 13:17.

questions.question: What command did Solomon give to Shimei, and what was the consequence if he disobeyed?
options: To build a house in Jerusalem and not leave; if he left, he would die
To serve as a servant in the palace; if he disobeyed, he would be exiled
To gather troops for the king; if he failed, he would be imprisoned
To offer sacrifices daily; if he failed, he would be cursed
questions.correctAnswer: To build a house in Jerusalem and not leave; if he left, he would die
questions.explanation: Solomon instructed Shimei to stay in Jerusalem under penalty of death if he left, emphasizing covenant obedience and consequences (1 Kings 2:36-37). This echoes Deuteronomy 28:15, Jeremiah 34:17, Ezekiel 18:20, and Hebrews 10:26-27 about obedience and judgment.

questions.question: What did Shimei do after living in Jerusalem for three years, and how did Solomon respond?
options: He went to Gath to retrieve his servants; Solomon ultimately executed him for breaking his oath
He remained obedient; Solomon rewarded him
He fled to Egypt; Solomon pardoned him
He rebelled openly; Solomon imprisoned him
questions.correctAnswer: He went to Gath to retrieve his servants; Solomon ultimately executed him for breaking his oath
questions.explanation: After three years, Shimei left Jerusalem to bring back servants, breaking his oath, leading Solomon to order his death (1 Kings 2:39-46). This illustrates divine justice and faithfulness to vows, consistent with Numbers 30:2, Psalm 15:4, Matthew 5:37, and James 5:12.

questions.question: How does this chapter illustrate the sovereignty of God over the Davidic kingship?
options: By showing that Solomon’s reign is established by the LORD according to His covenant promises
By highlighting Solomon’s military conquests
By emphasizing the wealth Solomon amassed
By showing Solomon’s building projects
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that Solomon’s reign is established by the LORD according to His covenant promises
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes that Solomon’s kingdom was firmly established by God fulfilling His promises to David (1 Kings 2:12, 2:24, 2:45-46). This sovereign establishment aligns with Psalm 89:19-37, Isaiah 9:6-7, Luke 1:32-33, and Acts 13:22-23 concerning God’s control and covenant faithfulness over the messianic line.

questions.question: What does Solomon’s handling of Adonijah, Joab, Abiathar, and Shimei teach about justice and mercy in God’s kingdom?
options: Justice is executed without partiality, but mercy is shown when past faithfulness is evident
Justice is delayed until the king’s death
Mercy is given to all regardless of actions
Justice is based on popularity
questions.correctAnswer: Justice is executed without partiality, but mercy is shown when past faithfulness is evident
questions.explanation: Solomon executes judgment on Adonijah and Joab but shows mercy to Abiathar due to his faithfulness (1 Kings 2:25-27). This balance reflects biblical justice and mercy principles found in Micah 6:8, Psalm 89:14, James 2:13, and Romans 12:19-21.
